Okay. Let's assuage your curiosity at the onset. Here's the answer to your million dollar question: No! apni Aishwarya doesn't disappear from the screen when you blink your eyes. Ever since her presence in Pink Panther was announced, the grapevine has been bustling with queries about the length and breadth of her role, with sceptics predicting a mere cosmetic presence. Remember Mallika Sherawat in Jackie Chan's The Myth?

Well, Ash may not have much to say in this Steve Martin show, other than stock lines. And, she may have spent most of her time as a svelte, also-starring, member of the Clouseau gang. But she plays a role that's of a completely different hue from her popular Bollywood avtars. Reason enough for the desi film buff to celebrate our desi girl's cross over. But of course, we, being the argumentative Indians, do have a niggling query...How come, most of the men have their hormones shooting up for the sober Nicole (Emily Mortimer), when actually, there ain't nobody like our desi girl? Strangely, nobody has the hots for Ash and both Andy Garcia and Steve Martin seem to go in a tizzy whenever the dumb, drab blonde's around. Ekdum hard to digest.

The film's a light and breezy comedy which you can definitely enjoy, if you stop looking for Peter Sellers in Steve Martin. Martin's Inspector Clouseau is a bumbling, bright old fella who bites the dust, whenever he is supposed to stand tall and vice versa. Elevated from his punishment posting as a traffic cop to the elite dream team set up to nab The Tornado, the new thief round the block, he sets out on a goofball mission that sees him doing the silliest things, with French panache. The Tornado has already stolen the Magna Carter, the sword of the Japanese Emperor and now wants to steal the famed diamond, The Pink Panther, which is a symbol of French honour. The international team of detectives, comprising stalwarts like Andy Garcia, Alfred Molina, Jean Reno, Aishwarya Rai, sets out on a roller coaster ride of upmanship.

Needless to say, it's affable old Clouseau who steals the show, with his antics, which include a hilarious rip-off as the Pope. And yes, his love-hate relationship with Chief Inspector Dreyfuss (John Cleese) literally sets the guns blaring. Don't expect a monumental performance by Aishwarya, and you'll find this sequel a pleasant viewing.

History records there were 15 assassination attempts on Hitler, and all of them were futile. For, the world's most controversial head of state actually committed suicide, nine months after a bombing attempt on him boomeranged. Valkyrie is a nail-biting historical thriller on this foiled assassination bid which might have changed the course of history if it had succeeded on July 20, 1944, when a bomb went off during Hitler's official briefing, causing just superficial burns to Der Fuehrer. The botched up attempt was followed by a series of arrests (700) and executions (200), even as Hitler's grandiose dreams of world domination were turning into a nightmare.

But Valkyrie isn't about the vengeance that followed; it is more about the man who might have ended up as history's biggest hero: Colonel Von Stauffenberg (Tom Cruise) who didn't mind being guilty of high treason, as long as he could save his country from ill-repute and disdain. With an eye patch and a disabled hand, Stauffenberg turns out to be the only unscarred German who managed to build a team of righteous men, ready to rid their country of the dictator with a dubious human rights' record. Stauffenberg not only manages to carry the bomb and place it right under Hitler's nose, he chalks out a meticulous military coup too and almost sets up a parallel government, after the explosion that might have blown an ordinary mortal into smithereens. But Hitler was destiny's child, or so it seemed. For even as Stauffenberg's men go about arresting the guilty Nazis, the radio sends out Hitler's broadcasts....

Bryan Singer has always been a skilful storyteller with a handle on the thriller noir. Remember Usual Suspects? Well, Valkyrie may not have the unpredictable twists that made Usual Suspects an Oscar winner, nevertheless, it does keep the adrenalin pumping, as you keep pace with this historical thriller that draws much of its appeal from the fact that it happened in the cataclysmic 1940s, where one aberration might have altered the course of world events. While Hitler largely figures as a silhouette in the film, it is Tom Cruise who remains with you as the tormented military man with a conscience that precluded him from raising his hand to `Hail Hitler!', the ubiquitous Nazi salute.

Brokeback Mountain may have come and gone, winning Oscars for its gay heroes and it's paean to sexual liberty. Just as 30 years may have passed since the assassination of gay activist, Harvey Milk. But the story of equality remains almost where it was, the world over. Homosexuality still isn't accepted as easily as heterosexuality and the closet is still tumbling out with `me too' stories of alternate sexual preferences.

Hence the importance of a biopic on Harvey Milk (Sean Penn), the first openly gay man who ran for public office in San Fransisco in the 1970s and ended up being elected as supervisor, after 3 failed attempts. From a champion of gay rights in a homophobic society, Milk metamorphosed into a human rights activist and became a national hero in his short life span which became a beacon of hope for any and every marginalised soul. And why not? Specially since there was a single credo behind every campaign that Milk initiated. He simply believed: All men are created equal. No matter how hard you tried, that could never be erased.

The film follows Milk's transformation from a carefree hippie who moves from New York to San Fransisco with his companion (James Franco), sets up a camera shop in the working class neighbourhood and decides to do something meaningful with his drifter's life. As a public officer, he campaigns for a gay rights' ordinance and unleashes a fiery fight against a ruling that empowers the government to sack people on the basis of their sexual preferences. This brings him in conflict with Dan White (Josh Brolin) a conservative Christian and a seemingly straight member of the Board of supervisors, who cannot accept this `ungodly' (that's what he believes) behavioural code. This is the beginning of a fateful relationship which culminates in a tumultuous climax.

Watch it for an unforgettable performance by Sean Penn who is heroic in his ordinariness, proving that outliers and high-flyers are made, not born.

Farah Khan and Zoya Akhtar aren't alone in going behind the silver curtain and uncovering the grime that lies beneath the glamour of tinsel town. Barry Levinson, the director who brought us the delectable political satire, Wag the Dog, now tries to give us a dekko at what lies out there in the chaos-ridden, cruel studios of Hollywood.

Based on the memoirs of Hollywood producer, Art Linson, the film traces the high drama that takes over the life of fading filmmaker, Ben (Robert DeNiro), as he tries to survive in a cut-throat industry that is forever on `delete' mode. On the one hand, Ben has a terrible film in the cans which faces the scissors at the studio screening itself. The film, which features Sean Penn in the lead, has a controversial climax of a dog being shot in the head. Reason enough for the studio heads to put it on hold. On the other hand, his new venture can't begin because the new hero, Bruce Willis has grown a beard and a bulging middle. Add to this, is Ben's still lingering passion for ex-wife, Robin Wright Penn, which makes the separation-therapy he's undergoing absolutely ineffective.

Recipe enough for loads of drama that keeps the entertainment meter alive and kicking. But not really something you'd expect from Raging Bull, Robert DeNiro..

Based on the self-help book written by Greg Berhendt and Liz Tuccillo, the film is a string of stories, loosely interwoven, with just one intention. They propose to tell you when a guy is interested in you and when is he trying to avoid you. How profound! Now, when did we need a book to unravel the mysteries of the heart. If only relationships could be worked out by flipping pages of a bestseller.

Forget the lament. The stories are actually light and easy viewing, although they might have crackled with a bit of comedy in them. The only funny story that makes you laugh is the desperate man hunt by a dotty Ginnifer Goodwin who spends most of her time staring at her phone, almost willing it to ring. She's waiting for the guy she met last night to call her back for another date, maybe tonight. Of course, no one calls back and Ginnifer wonders whether she's the exception or the rule when it comes to love fulfilled.

The other confused in-love, out-of-love Baltimore girls include Jennifer Aniston who's wondering why Ben Affleck doesn't propose marriage, despite living with her for seven long years; Jennifer Connelly who is willing to forgive her husband a one-night stand, but can't handle his covert smoking; Scarlett Johansson who falls in love with a married man who feels too guilty after succumbing to her charms. And finally, there's Drew Barrymore who finds mates easily on MySpace but can't seem to attract anyone in real life.

This one's sheer candy floss, meant for a Valentine viewing. Don't go looking for heart-tugging romance and you won't end up disappointed.

Boyz will be boys. And cars will be cars. Fast and furious; spinning out of control; racing, bumping, crashing into each other at god-knows-what speed! Anyone for the thin plot line? A gorgeous young automobile fanatic and front to the hottest unsigned band on the West coast, Natasha Martin (Nadia Bjorlin) is the racing beauty who finds herself caught up in illegal drag-racing competitions organised for the pleasure of a bunch of bored billionaires. Also, meet the leader of the pack, Infamous (Eddie Griffin) and Carlos, the soldier (Nathan Phillips) who comes home from Iraq, only to end up as Natasha's knight in shining armour.

Despite a poor plot, there's enough to keep the testosterone-filled spirits upbeat, specially for speed addicts and auto freaks with the rollicking car parade that includes the likes of a Phantom Rolls Royce, Lamborghini Murcielago, Enzo Ferrari, Ferrari F430, Ferrari Scaglietti, Mercedes SLR, McLaren AMGs...

Will Smith is determined to swing both ways, in terms of artistic exploration. If, on the one hand he wants to give his viewers an adrenalin high with films like Men in Black, I Legend and Hancock, he also wants them to remember him as a high performer with soul-stirring acts like The Pursuit of Happiness and now, Seven Pounds.

Ben Thomas (Will Smith) is the most unusual tax man in town. Unlike the sharks in the IRS, this sad man with soulful eyes goes looking for deserving people who should be given a tax break. Some tax man! Living all by himself in a fleabag motel, with a jelly fish for company, he hunts all day for suitable men and women who deserve a favour. And finds them in the usual places: in hospitals, bars and broken homes, where the almost dead and the hopeless wait for sordid ends. Forlorn Ben not only befriends them, he even finds a solution to their problems and ends up like the friendly neighbourhood Spiderman, albeit without the web and the flying fetish.

And in the course of playing Good Samaritan, he manages to find love too, with beautiful, lonely Rosario Dawson who will die in a few months, if her pager doesn't ring. She has a congenital heart problem and the hospital has promised to page her if they find a donor. But love too turns out to be forbidden for angst-ridden Ben who desperately tries to turn his back to a second chance, only because it's redemption rather than romance that our hero is scouting for.

So, is he doomed to rest content with a single night of passion that follows a romantic candle-lit dinner or can the music play on, past the morning too? Seven Pounds is a sincerely told, mushy tale about spreading good cheer and making the world a better place, with Smith essaying the role of the tormented do-gooder with impeccable zeal.

Based on the bestseller by journalist John Grogan, the film is a must for dog lovers. Marley, the Grogan's hyperactive labrador, isn't just a dog you see. He's actually the counsellor who keeps the family together through their sundry ups and downs, which are actually part and parcel of every young couple's life.

John (Owen Wilson) and Jenny (Jennifer Aniston) are two ambitious, young journalists in South Florida who adopt Marley, before they start their family. It doesn't take long for them to recognise their dog's destructive tendencies and they brand him the `lovable' hound from hell. For Marley eats up everything, including the answering machine and a diamond necklace and transforms their house into a messed up, much lived-in home. Soon, the couple undergo the usual trauma of parenthood, with both having to compromise on their careers for the sake of their family and the relationship enters rough weather. But there's Marley, remember: the only constant in their changing lives. He's there when the babies cry the night through with colic. He's there when Jenny needs some comfort and care while tending to her brood. And he's there with John on the seaside, listening man-to-man, as his master pours out his angst to him.

So what's the glue that keeps the family together? Marley and his unconditional love for the Grogan family, which demands nothing from them, except their heart. This one's for a mushy, sentimental family viewing, with the doggoned tale of a man's best friend.

The film is a witty adaptation of journalist Toby Young's autobiographical account of the years he spent at Vanity Fair and his brush with Page 3 journalism. Of course, it doesn't exactly get as inventive when lifting the veils on celebrity journalism as The Devil Wears Prada did with the fashion world, but the misadventures of Simon Pegg in Sharp magazine do have their malicious moments.

Journalist Sidney Young, a news hound who gets the celeb gossip any which way, gets a chance to move uptown when a New York publisher (Jeff Bridges) offers him a job in Sharp, his popular hobnob-with-Hollywood magazine. Now, getting close to celebs in a megapolis isn't quite easy as it seems, specially when your hormones are on overboil whenever you come in close contact with starlets like Sophie Maes (Megan Fox) and their hard-as-nails publicists like Eleanor Johnson (Gillian Anderson). But Young has co-worker, Kirsten Dunst to help him through the slithery maze, even though he can hardly see the hidden ardour in her eyes.

Welcome to the glitz and grime of the paparazzi people. Peppy stuff.

Nothing outlandish about this one, specially if you've seen the more evolved versions of alien monsters, like Predator and Species. Also, the film unfolds mostly in the dark, so you're left rubbing your eyes for a better dekko of the gooey apparition that is supposed to terrorise you. All you can make out of this extra-terrestrial goop is orange eyes, a giant beetle's silhouette and some yucky saliva.

They call him Moorwen. At least that's what the alien, Kanian (Jim Caviezel) who accompanied him to planet earth tells us. And Kanian would know, since Moorwen was a stowaway on his space ship, as it crash landed on terra firma during the Iron Age. While Moorwen flees into the neigbouring forests and begins to feast himself on the villagers, Kainan is held captive by the Vikings who mistake him for the marauder. Doesn't take long before the Viking king realises he is actually their saviour and encourages his feisty daughter (Sophia Myles) to have a bit of fun on the side, since she's already betrothed to another Viking warrior (Jack Huston).

Anyone know what Caviezel is doing in a film like this, after having wowed you with his Jesus Christ avtar in Mel Gibson's The Passion of the Christ?

America may have its first black president, but there are still a lot of stories left to be told about racism and the rise of black power in the US. Honeydripper is one such sensitive tale of self-esteem and survival in Alabama during the 1950s, when most black people were supposed to pick cotton on the white man's farm.

Entrepreneurship was obviously neither meant nor expected from them. Hence, the importance of Danny Glover who tries to run a small pub, despite the hostile environs around him.

Honeydripper is Glover's little beer joint which has hit upon bad days and is fast losing out on business. The harried man has just a few days to clear his debts or else he loses his eatery, which once was the most popular jazz joint in the neighbourhood.

He sacks his old jazz singer and decides to bring on a popular city guitarist to rev up the music and bring in the customers. But the guitarist fails to turn up and Glover thinks it's time to pull down the shutters when his step daughter reminds him of Sunny (Gary Clark Jr), the guitar-toting vagabond they had fed once. Sunny and his strange new guitar (read electric) not only mark a new beginning for Glover's business, they also usher in the age of rock 'n roll in this small hamlet that's trying to keep pace with the march of history.

Like a rich and fading tapestry, the film successfully manages to create a lost world, a lost time. That we may never forget.

There was a Kill Bill and there is a dead Bill. Of course, there are no similarities between this deadpan comedy about Bill's search for identity and Quentin Tarantino's high octane action film, other than the title.

But titles can be terribly misleading, as can the cast. The filmmakers commit harakiri by reducing Jessica Alba to a mere tag-along-girl who steps in when Eckhart's wife (Elizabeth Banks) is busy with a bit on the side. And when Alba's not playing proxy, she's playing crosswords with a precocious little school boy. Simply not done.

Middle-aged Bill (Aaron Eckhart) is on the cross roads of his life. His job sucks, his wife's cheating on him and his midriff's swelling. The only thing he digs are doughnuts, which obviously aren't good for him.

And adding to his litany of woes is this new mentor programme, where he is saddled with a teen schoolboy who thinks life is fun, just fun. It doesn't take long for Bill to realise the boy's actually right and soon he's ready for a physical and mental make-over after shedding the gangrene off his life.

So, who's mentoring whom? Camp fires, crackers, pyjama parties coupled with some hardballed fisticuffs is all it takes to make befuddled Bill come of age. Only, the fun parts seem to elude the viewer completely in this meandering, plotless venture.

He's the archetypal Mr Under-Appreciated by now. For Adam Sandler has never really digressed from his first few roles of the affable underdog that made him a household name, some years ago. And like all 70 mm underdogs, Sandler too is a topdog in disguise. It doesn't take long for our bumbling hero to walk away with the Ferrari and the fair maiden, just like all those perfect Prince Charmings in the fairy tales. So how can it be any different with Bedtime Stories, where Sandler is actually supposed to tell happily-ever-after stories to two young kids. The metaphor must live on....

Loser Sandler ends up as a handyman in the hotel his father built, simply because he isn't smart, urbane, yuppie, cocky. Or better still, he isn't Mr Butt Kisser, like his rival, Kendall (Guy Pearce) who not only plans to walk away with the top job, but also with the hot girl, who happens to be the owner's Paris Hilton-ish daughter.

Having been bred on his father's bedtime stories, Sandler still believes fairy tales don't have sad endings. This belief is reiterated by his young nephew and niece, when he babysits them for a few nights, while their mom (Courtney Cox) goes job hunting. The kids always find a happy ending for his sad bedtime stories which always feature him as the loser hero, dreaming to grow from handyman to hotel incharge.

Time for the magic to begin. One by one, the stories begin to turn true. It actually rains gumballs in drab real life, the fair maiden almost kisses him, the Ferrari seems to be round the corner and the zero is all set to metamorphose into a hero.

This may not quite be the best from sad sack Sandler's gag bag, nevertheless, there's enough gooey stuff to keep the sweetness flowing. The film has some zany moments when Sandler's strange bedtime stories are actually translated on screen, complete with mermaids, monsters, gladiators, robots and space wars. But the essence lies in the emotional core, where Sandler tries to prove to the kids that he isn't the bad guy. He's the hero!This one's good timepass family fare.

FORGET the twitter about aggrieved national sentiment. For, Slumdog Millionaire is neither poverty porn nor slum tourism. No, unlike what the desi nationalists' blogosphere claims, it is not a case of the infamous western eye ferreting out oriental squalor and peddling it as the exotic dirt bowl of the east. No, Slumdog Millionaire is just a piece of riveting cinema, meant to be savoured as a Cinderella-like fairy tale, with the edge of a thriller and the vision of an artist. It was never meant to be a documentary on the down and out in Dharavi. And it isn't.
Danny Boyle actually treads into familiar territory. He takes the typical Bollywood tale of two brothers who have only one mission in life: survival. And he takes them through the usual ups and downs that we have witnessed so many times in the best and the worst of Bollywood masala: the tenements, the riots, the underworld, the brothels, the streets, the gutters, the stations, the separations, the reunions, the friendships, the rivalry, love, longing, despair...followed by final victory. And this heartwarming stayin' alive saga unfolds dramatically against the backdrop of Mumbai's underbelly, which stands by as a throbbing witness to the coming-of-age of its three protagonists, the three musketeers, Jamal Malik (Dev Patel), Salim Malik (Madhur Mittal) and Latika (Frieda Pinto).

For those who are hoping to find a straight biopic about the legendary singer, this one's definitely not the ‘Once there was Robert Allen Zimmerman aka Bob Dylan' kinda thing. It's stylish, staccato, surreal but never straight. So don't go looking for how and when Dylan wrote Blowin' in the Wind and you might just find all the answers floating in the text and sub-text.

Dylan himself strikes the note of the film when he confesses in a smoke-laden moment of introspection: ``I accept chaos. I don't know whether it accepts me.'' And the chaos theory prevails as you try and keep pace with the sundry versions of the singer played by different artists.

The story begins with a boy Bob Dylan who calls himself Woody Guthrie and already displays the trappings of the vagabond sage who learns his first lesson from a kind old woman. She tells him to sing about his times. And times, they are a 'changing. So there you have Dylan, protesting against everything that's wrong in society and politics.

Sometimes as the Greenwich Village folk singer, Jack (Christian Bale) and sometimes as Robbie (Heath Ledger), the family man struggling through a marriage marred by Vietnam, apathy, angst. The most notable avtar however is that of the androgynous Jude, played to perfection by Cate Blanchett. Blanchett encapsulates the restless energy and the high anxiety of the artist, like never before. Somehow, all his songs make so much more sense after Jude desperately wrings his hands and declares: ``Protest is all I do...Who cares what I think? I'm not the President. I'm just a storyteller.'' Dylan fans, do not miss.

Story: Baillie Walsh's this dramatic film begins on a promising note. As the opening credits start rolling, the music played in the background soothes your heart and the visuals of the enchanting friendship shared between two young boys make you nostalgic. As the song progresses the director impressively contaminates the existing serene ambience by flashing visuals of an ageing Joe (Daniel Craig) having a night of three-way sex and cocaine orgy. At the crack of dawn, we see Joe sprawled on his bed... lying naked (wonder if the scene will make it to theatres here in India) as an aftermath of the drugs filled orgy and we get a cue that the man is leading a troubled life and needs help.

Review: As we'd expect, Joe happens to be an ageing movie star whose career is going to dogs, owing to his own eccentric behaviour. He uses a concealer to hide his dark circles but finds it unable to hide his regrets. He leads an isolated life in his plush Malibu mansion and avoids reminiscing his past until his friend Boots dies. On getting the news Joe finally sets off for a journey that takes him back to his inglorious past and here is when the 'flashbacks' begin without Daniel Craig but actor Harry Eden playing the lead instead.
