1928. A single mother (Angelina Jolie) in Los Angeles returns after a hard day's work to find her son missing. Like any law abiding citizen, she takes the recourse of law and goes to the LAPD with her problem.

And like any tax paying citizen, she believes the police department will find her son the sole lifeline in her vapid life someday, even though its five months now since he disappeared. Culpable Jolie. Confused Jolie. She somehow got it all wrong. For how can the cops solve her problem, when they were the problem themselves.

Familiar story? Well, Bollywood may have milked the corrupt cop story dry by now, but for Clint Eastwood, it's a tale that needs to told with all the characteristic anger, pathos and power that is part and parcel of his oeuvre.

And like Million Dollar Baby, this time too, he finds an unsual female protagonist: a frail, vulnerable, genteel lady who takes on the might of the powerful police department, when other well-meaning townsmen have failed. these include, John Malkovich, the preacher, who has been campaigning against their cruel, brute force in his radio shows.

The problem begins when the cops claim to have solved the mystery and deposit another little boy in Jolie's care, even though she insists he's not her son. When her protests get too loud, they put her in a mental institution for her share of the One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest crunch.

Running parallel is another track of a psychopath who seems to have a fondness for axing kids in a chicken coop. Jolie's son may have been a victim too, but Jolie's fight isn't just that of a mourning mother. For her, it's a larger cause, where justice must prevail for all her newfound friends: the women who have been incarcerated in mental homes due to police brutality.

Jolie may have lost out on the Golden Globe for her wide and wet-eyed portrayal of the crusading mother, but the Oscar buzz still remains. The film has been directed as a detailed period piece about an age when no one thought of photographic evidence or DNA testing. Yet, despite its gritty overtones, this one falls short of Eastwood's other highs, Unforgiven and Million Dollar Baby.

The perfect match or Mr Sparky? Now that's a tough choice for a woman to make, specially when she knows it's time to settle down, happily, sedately, securely, ever after. Also, it becomes difficult if Mr Right translates into the congenial Colin Firth who promises a life full of neat answers and solutions.

That's the dilemma that Agony Aunt, Uma Thurman must resolve on the eve of her wedding. Shouldn't be difficult, specially since Ms Thurman is a relationship expert and runs a successful radio show on How to Find a Suitable Man and Keep Him Forever! But when did love work on a formula?

So, Thurman finds herself being irresistibly drawn towards the strange and winsome firefighter (Jeffrey Dean Morgan) who lives in an Indian-dominated Queens and celebrates Indian Bar Mitzvahs with gusto, besides accompanying her to the caterers and serenading her in the lift.Sweet, funny and romantic, this one isn't great; just good timepass.

The film which opened the Goa IFFI and was premiered at Cannes, Blindness is an end-of-civilisation fable which is thought-provoking and topical in its indictment of declining social mores.

The film uses blindness as a metaphor for societal disintegration. It focuses on the behaviour of a city spilling over with people who are losing their sight and are forced to survive in a sea of whiteness.

Sightlessness spreads like an affliction and forces the city officials to put the affected people in a prison-like institution, where no one can see, except Julianne Moore.

Soon, the makeshift hospital becomes a microcosm of a jungle, where only the fittest will survive and values might just end up as encumbrances in a free-for-all society.

Can Julianne Moore use her sight to save her husband and her room mates from the animal-like predators next door? Is this newfound kinship better than the dysfunctional social relationships before? Is man actually bestial, when stripped down to the basics?

Watch Blindness for a chilling dissection of the civilised world that we presume to have built around us.

A real estate swindler (Rob Schneider) faces a prison sentence and is mortally scared of the louts that lie in wait for him behind bars.
He has six months before he actually ends up with them, hence, he uses the time to learn some smart survival tips from a down and out martial arts trainer (David Carradine).

End result? He ends up the biggest dada of them all.Funny, all the way, but only if you are ready for some low brow humour.

The world shall be eternally thankful to George W Bush. Not for his botched up policies, ideas and ideology, but for opting to don the role of the First Joker rather that the First Citizen. Never have we laughed so much on the antics of a world leader who chose to be goofy even in America's bleakest hour. Remember 9/11 and how he held `My Pet Goat', a children's story book, upside down, while the airplanes pounded history!

Well, Bush may be on his way out and what better way to bid him farewell than celebrate his Bushisms with a dash of Indianisms. The President is Coming is an amateurish, yet funny satire that not only lampoons Bush, but also takes a rib-tickling dekko at the stereotype of the Indian youth.

Set against the US president's visit to India, the film is a behind-the-scenes of the US consulate which has been given the arduous task of selecting one suitable young Indian who will shake hands with Dubya. Needless to say, this fortunate (read unfortunate) Indian will be the sole representative of India's burgeoning youth population and will have to showcase the mantra of `India Shining-Rising-Rocking,' all in a split second.

Enter, Shernaz Patel, the quirky, dominatrix PR agent who must select the chosen one with her assistant, the second-sexed Ritu Johnson (Shivani Tanksale). Enter too, the participants: an odd assortment of twenty-something Indians who have to pass a test of their physical and mental skills before they have their tryst with history. And, it's here the fun begins, as the wannabe Booker winner; Konkona tries to outwit the rest with her snooty pseudo-intellectual airs. Of course, she's no competition for the casteist-communal swadeshi MBA pass out, the Yankee-fied accent trainer, the bimbette desi Paris Hilton (Ira Dubey), the gay geek who wants a good wife and the earthy stock broker who believes money can buy everything, even a handshake!

The film has a raw look and lacks finesse when it comes to production values. But there is a delightful tongue-in-cheek tenor running through it, which makes you overlook the unpolished feel and the loose editing. While George Bush himself is reduced to a bunch of raucous snores and a disembodied flick of the hand, India's famous Gen Xer's are themselves a bunch of nerds who think Colin Powell is Nelson Madela and Osama is Bhagwan Rajneesh.

But in the end, despite their foibles, they are all lovable and recognizable, including the `communal' wannabe entrepreneur who ends up befriending the Muslim guard and applauding his Urdu poetry. Performance-wise, it's the uptight and complex-ridden Ms Konkona who walks away with laurels and laughs even as the film takes a healthy snigger at the desi self.

BAZ Luhrmann is contemporary cinema's biggest, boldest maverick movie moghul. Having burst onto the world stage with Romeo and Juliet, his punkish adaptation of William Shakespeare, he brought back colour and melodrama to modern folklore with his stagey musical, Moulin Rouge. Australia, another magnum opus, is his ode to the pristine beauty of the continent down under, even as it creates a sweeping romance, with race as the leitmotif, reminiscent of Gone With The Wind.

Set against the tumult of World War ll, the director shifts his drama to Australia, complete with it's characteristic slangs, lingo, cows, horses, farming, landscape, aborigines, celebrations, folktales, beer, the beef industry and above all, the dreams of the people who were affected by the fallout of history. And that's not all in Baz Luhrmann's Aussie continent. There's a good English First Lady, Lady Sarah Ashley (Nicole Kidman), who sets out to seek her husband and then to fight for his cause. In due course bumping into kangaroos, native women who are easy to get along with 'only if you try' and the Aussie cowboy, Drover (Hugh Jackman) -- also the trusted man of the husband. What follows is a love affair, a battle between cattle barons, the bombing of Darwin Harbor and a lesson in aboriginal acceptance. In short, there's something for each one of you out there.

Cut to the performances. Nicole Kidman lives up to her image of the original Oz in Hollywood, not just as the aristocrat who is quite a looker, but also as Mrs Boss for the neither-black-nor-white folks in town. Reasons enough to overlook her ignorance at horse riding, singing, story telling and playing mom. Jackman too is a delight as the rugged and handsome Drover whom, 'no man can hire and no man can fire'.

But stealing the show as a surprise element is the aboriginal boy, Nullah (Brandon Walters), right from his love for the rainbow song to the little magic and his connection with King George. In fact, as a perfect narrator, he ties the first half (the cattle drive), the second half (the bombing of Darwin Harbor), the all-through love story of Sarah and the drover together. All this and more, till he best sums up Australia: 'When in Australia, do not look, but see!'

Indeed, a film that any film buff would love to see! And savour.

THIS one's for all those into graveyard shifts at BPO units: Before they teach you their accent, ask them to learn about India. At least, you won't have the typically amrikan queries coming your way. Try these: Why do Indians call Chicaaago Chicago? Why do Indians shake their heads each time they need to say a yes or no? Why do Indians worship the goddess of destruction? Why do Indian roads have cows all over? Why do Indians work when Americans sleep?

Life's a relentless question mark for products salesman Todd Anderson (Josh Hamilton) when he is sent to India to train his replacement. And giving the desi, chatpata reply is none other than the intelligent and focussed Asha (Ayesha Dharker) who tells the world that India rocks because this is where kids do not walk out of homes when in their teens, we don't hate our jobs and we don't hate our bosses. But the real Indianism, that's incidentally nothing less than a desi englightenment for Mr Todd is our very own bura-na-mano holi hai festival. So, does he mind the colour riot? Not all all. After all, hitting gulal ain't no different than a baseball game. Truly incredible...

And truly incredible is the power of Incredible India. How? Well, desi cliches no longer seem to be cliches. Todd doesn't mind being called Toad by the humble desi, dancing to Bollywood tunes becomes the ultimate experience for him, the first dip in the nearby pond is nothing less than nirvana, the goddess of destruction is there for him to 'destruct in order to start a new cycle of life'...

Last but not the least, a special mention for Puro (Asif Basra), at the local call centre who does not mind getting riled provided his boss takes the right meal at the right time and the topical undercurrent of the BPO industry -- China is the new India with 20 heads worth the price of one. But the heart of the film comes from Todd's blossoming relationship with the Asha. This time for her cardamom body odour and third-eye-power (the shakti of the bhartiya nari that lies in her bindi), her mantra of do-no-touch-me-in-public-in-india, her faith in arranged marriages despite her dalliance with Mr America.

This one's surely for the spirit of Indiyeah!

IN Bruges, you learn to live by the heart alone; by your soul alone; by your conscience alone; for your principles alone. So what's Bruges? It's actually a small, picturesque town in Belgium, but here it becomes a metaphor for purgatory, where three killers get a chance to choose hell or heaven. It's a smart gangster film, with some high powered acting by Colin Farrell as the conscience-stricken, suicidal hitman who has killed a small boy on his first assignment. Colin's manic energy is finely juxtaposed against Gleeson's cool kind-heartedness, despite the fact that he is the senior partner in this crime syndicate and has the most difficult mission at hand. And behind the odd duo is Ralph Fiennes, the boss who is a diehard family man apart from being a determined killer who comes down to Bruges to settle scores on his own when his hitman fail.
An absolute delight.

FIVE months... Four weeks.... Three days... Two hours... One minute... Welcome to the grand finale of a tween reality dance show. A world that's full of dance and dazzle -- comprising jazz, waltz, balllets, auditions, semi-final and prop rounds. And loads of razzle that stem from the survival-of-the fittest syndrome, creative controversies, judges who feel 'there is no room for political correctness in dance', blackouts of kids with high anxiety levels... This one's a telling comment on the competitive new age peopled by pushy helicopter moms and their over-ambitious kids.

First there is Justin Morgan who takes pride in daughter Tenille, who learnt German in three minutes, can dance like Mariah Carey, can sing under water and above all, can be forced to show her moves even as she trips and falls on stage. Second there's Paulette Gibson who claims her daughter Graci is 'an incredibly driven and competitive child'. As for the baba log, while Tenille's convinced that the judges get it all wrong each time she performs, Graci knows that 'mom always knows best.' All this revved up hungama happens in the high octane backdrop of Mr Jonathan and Ms Elizabeth's dance school.

But what really keeps glittering in this razzle dazzle of reality shows is Darren Ashton’s own chicken curry for the soul. What’s that? No, not the young breed of accolade hunters who impress all with their moves. Or for that matter, Ben Miller’s performance, followed by that of Kerry Armstrong as a pushy stage mother -- indeed noteworthy. Well, it's the surprisingly mockumentary touch to the good 'ol Shakespearean funda with an emphasis on say-no-to-sexism -- All the world's just a competitive stage and all men and women are winners! And that's 'the new revolution of dance'!

Are the new age parents listening?

Alex, the King of New York returns with his buddies, Marty, the smart-ass zebra (Chris Rock), Melman, the why-so-serious giraffe (David Schwimmer) and Gloria, the lovelorn hippo (Jada Pinkett Smith), after having charmed us with their escapades in Madagascar, their first adventure. Their second outing is equally charming too, with eye-popping visuals, vibrant animation, rib-tickling teasers and a joyous abandon that makes for perfect tweeny fare.

movie

It's Been a relentless run for Jason Statham, over the past few weeks. Even as Transporter 3 still manages to find viewers, the action hero returns with a period film where he pummels his way through mayhem, once again. This time, he is determined to rescue his family after they are abducted by a mysterious tribe of creatures called the Krugs.

Set in a strange era -- the kingdom of Ehb -- where kings were poisoned and evil magicians ruled, the film has a dark, sepia tone that doesn't quite match up to the visual splendour of 300, which had similar shades. Even the action seems muted and low key, which is quite a heresy for a Statham film. 'Cause the only reason a viewer comes to watch this dour hit machine is to applaud his hits.
Ironically, there are too many misses, this time round.

THE Going's getting good for lovers of alternate cinema; one that lives and throbs beyond the hegemony of Hollywood. The Page Turner is a taut French thriller that treats the leitmotif of revenge like vintage wine that grows more heady with age.

Young Melanie has been nurturing and feeding her desire for vendetta against Madame Fouchecourt, a famous pianist, ever since she was a kid. The artist had been invited to judge her in a piano recital but had been more busy signing autographs than paying attention to the wannabe pianist's performance. A distracted Melanie fails to clear her class, shuts her piano, locks up her dreams and grows up into a young, mysterious woman, spilling over with venom against the woman who squashed her dreams. She charms her way into the lady's house, becomes her page turner, accompanies her to her concerts, becomes an indispensable part of her life...And then strikes back.
Thrilling stuff, with riveting performances and uplifting music.

FOR All you naysayers out there, here's one word that can change your life: YES! This three-letter word could just be your ticket for a rollercoster ride through life which could see you boarding a plane to Nebraska, for nothing at all, learning Korean, JLT, making-out in the middle of the road, minus all hang-ups, helping the homeless, sharing coffee with an unknown Iranian friend, hanging upside down from a bridge or even talking a man out of his suicidal mood. Of course, not forgetting grabbing a few promotions along the way, for your pro-active positivism at work or finding true love that's zany, crazy and completely unconventional.

Jim Carrey may have sobered down somewhat, with his wrinkles and greys. But the funny man of Mask is still funny, minus the mask. As Carl, the bank officer, he pumps up the show, more with his middle-aged musings, than with the characteristic contortions of his facial muscles. A proverbial `NO' man, Carl undergoes a client empowerment programme which entails that he say `Yes' to every opportunity, if he really wants to hop aboard the success bandwagon. Difficult, but do-able, says the determined Carrey and begins to say yes to any and everything, however bizarre and improbable it may be.

Truly, this is the magic mantra that has our hero hopping in and out of inconvenient situations, but always ending up a winner. He not only wins friends and influences people, he finds a funny girl (Zooey Deschanel of The Happening fame) too who also believes in the credo: normal is boring. She hurtles on a scooter, sings in a weird rock band, shoots pictures while running and teaches fitness to a bunch of loonies at the crack of dawn.

It's a breezy, light-hearted film with some truly comic moments with Carrey displaying a newfound maturity. Catch him ending up as a terrorist suspect, simply because he took flying lessons and learnt Korean, and you'll know America is ready to laugh at itself, post 9/11.

THE Film may be set in the battlefield of World War l, but it's message rings loud and clear, even today. For here, in the midst of death, destruction, war and violence, the armies of the feuding nations -- the Scott, the French, the Germans -- learn the most important lesson of history. One that declares, in unambiguous terms, that war is meaningless. Because humanity is one; there are no enemies in this overarching brotherhood of man. Supplant war with terror, and this multi-lingual film which has won applause at sundry international film festivals, becomes almost mandatory viewing.

It's Christmas eve. The crusading armies decide to issue a temporary cease fire and crawl out of their trenches after they hear a famous German tenor set aside bullets and bloodshed and split the air with his soulful rendition of `Silent Night.' Soon, the German tenor and his mate (Diane Kruger), a guest on the front lines, are joined by the Scott and the French and the enmities are set aside for a combined mass, followed by football, champagne and loads of camaraderie. Soldiers who were brutally killing each other a short while ago are now sharing photographs of their loved ones and inviting each other for wine and song, once the war is over. Of course, nobody wants to ask the key question: how many of us will survive this needless violence?

Christmas comes and goes. Ironically, the war doesn't. The hapless commanders of the respective armies are made to pay the price for their rationality in this season of hate, where young children sing songs of annihilation and priests send out the believers to kill the `vile OTHER', in the name of God.
Do not miss this strong and stirring anti-war statement.

RICHARD Gere and Terence Howard make a formidable pair on screen as a pair of journalists who have been covering the war in Bosnia and get back together again, when the war is over, to settle old scores. The film is a scorcher all the way. On the one hand, you get to witness some of the finest onscreen chemistry between a cranky, has-been Gere who cracked up while covering the atrocities of war and a more balanced Howard who left the dangerous terrain for more cushy assignments, without giving up his yen for the real thing. The fire is rekindled when the duo get back together again in Bosnia, this time to capture a war criminal who seems to enjoying the patronage of the CIA.

But that's just one part of the drama. The second, more interesting facet is the multi-layered plot which makes allusions to bin Laden and the abortive bids to nab him and to the horrors of ethnic strife that are tearing the world apart. It's a gritty, nerve-wracking thriller that sees this unusual threesome -- seasoned journos, Gere and Howard and Harvard graduate, greenhorn Eisenberg -- embark on a do-or-die mission that has danger lurking at every twisted bend. Get your thrills.

If mankind doesn't bother about the Inconvenient Truth (remember, the environmental degradation), then aliens are going to take care. The new eco warriors are going to be a towering iron man and a tuxedo-clad Keanu Reeves who will come all the way from out there in a huge sphere that lands in the middle of Central Park, Manhattan, and begin their Save Earth mission. So what if this entails the annihilation of the entire human race! Earth, the only planet that can support complex life forms, must be saved from ecological apocalypse, any which way.

The film is essentially a re-make of a 1951 film and traces the journey of an alien, Klaatu (Keanu Reeves) in New York, as he tries to evade the aggressive US forces, a shrewish secretary of defence (Kathy Bates) and an army of earthlings (scientists, cops, doctors) ready to capture him and put him in the petri dish, for research and experimentation. His only friend in this hostile territory seems to be doctor Connelly who understands Klaatu's concerns and begs him to help humans save themselves and their planet.

Now the premise of the film does hold promise, but the execution is lack-lustre and minus all special effects. Now warranted at all, specially since sci-fi cinema has had a quantum leap since 1951, when the first version of the film was made. Dark, despairing, run-of-the-mill stuff.

A gripping docu-feature, Still Life focuses on the woes of development that leaves people homeless, uprooted and migrants for life. Based on the real life Three Gorges Dam Project on the Yangste River which demolished the entire ancient town of Fenjgie, the camera accompanies the two protagonists -- a coal mine worker and a nurse -- who travel to this ancient town to seek out their respective spouses.

While Sanming hasn't seen his bride and teenage daughter for 16 years, Shen Hong is determined to find her truant husband in order to divorce him.

The film offers a compelling picture of the social and economic tumult that China, or any other developing nation, must undergo before it actually arrives on the global map of developed nations.

THE Coen brothers are famous for their quirky little films that spill over with unpredictable characters and teasing plots and sub-plots. Burn After Reading may not be their best, but it is an arresting piece of a crime-gone-awry drama with an unconventional act by both George Clooney and Brad Pitt who discover their negative shades with apblomb.

The plot links together a bunch of assorted characters and stretches from the US intelligence agencies to a downtown gym, leading up to the Russian embassy as a bunch of gym employees (Pitt and McDormand) lay their hands on the unpublished memoirs of a disgruntled CIA agent (John Malkovich).

Pitt ends up in Malkovich's house, in order to blackmail him, but gets embroiled in a do-or-die confrontation with his wife's lover (George Clooney), instead. Clooney, meanwhile, loves to find companions through the internet and is in the middle of a clandestine affair with Pitt's partner-in-crime, McDermond, who is determined to sell the CIA memoirs to the Russians.

Zany, crazy stuff that needed some pace to really spruce up the drama.

The Transporter is back. This time with a human cargo: the kidnapped Natalya Rudakova who needs to be delivered to her father, a high-ranking Ukaranian government official.

But before he can deliver his delectable package, he must contend with the blackguards who are hell bent on putting a spanner in his mission. Rudely interrupted by a trespassing car that breaks into his bedroom, while he is watching TV, the Transporter dons his best suit and drives off with the mysterious red head.

For all Transporter fans, the good news is that part three of this high-adrenalin action flick is a few shades better than the desultory part two. Jason Statham is a fitting follow-up of Steven Segal and Jean Claude Van Demme and does manage to deliver a class act as the emotionless action hero who kicks butts, kills and then cleans up, donning a crisp white shirt immediately after the mayhem.

Rest assured, the film doesn't leave you bored at all and even offers you some classic action cuts. Paisa vasool entertainment!

WHEN The Unfaithful, aka Richard Gere and Diane Lane turn faithful in the celluloid version of Nicholas Sparks' novel — The Notepad — romance is sure to be aplenty. Set in the picturesque town of Rodanthe, the story focuses on the unhappily married Adrienne (Daine Lane), whose life revolves around her two children, her career, a broken marriage, memories of her dead father. And her buddy, Jane. Really sad. So she takes a break from her dismal life,leaves her two kids with her husband and temporarily takes charge of her friend's picturesque North Carolina coastal inn. All she gets to hear at the inn is that the hurricane is a-coming...coming...coming. Till it finally comes.

No, not the hurricane, but Dr Paul (Richard Gere), one of those lonely Jaguar-driving geniuses straight from the operating room. Now that's another story that this lonely man hates to eat alone, drive alone and be alone, even as he almost crucifies himself right through the film for being a 'bad man, bad doctor, bad husband, bad father, bad... bad... bad!' But there's the hurricane, remember? That's the only bright spot in the dismal lives of the two inmates, specially since it brings them together in a clandestine relationship. The harried twosome end up setting aside the woes of the world and finding love and solace in the arms of each other.

The script is stale, the narrative tardy. What works is the chemistry of Diane Lane and Richard Gere which has already been displayed in two films, The Unfaithful and The Cotton Club. Here, they replay their passion as two damaged souls who serenade each other langorously through sealed envelopes, stamped letters and weeks of waiting. No e-chats, no SMes, not even telephone calls. Truly, a period love song!

SO what if film titles based on a videogames do not achieve many players (read viewers)? At least some of them manage to attain a certain degree of entertainment value, like Resident Evil, Hitman and now the most commercialised, dhoom-dhamaka Hollywood offering of the week based on a violent videogame — May Payne.

Max Payne lives up to the video gaming formula and offers loads of action, drama, violence, albeit with characters that need no joystick to explode. The story also kowtows the plot of the game with Max Payne (Mark Wahlberg) being an NYPD cop who may be pushing files right now, but his insides are seething with revenge. He is hell bent on avenging the murder of his wife, baby and his best buddy. And that's exactly where his pain stems from. The outcome? He does not believe in 'heaven, but in pain, fear, death and angels'. No wonder he's all out Batmanish ishtyle against a major pharmaceutical outfit figure in the form of a winged demon (read Valkyrie) flying all over the NY city.

Add to that invincible super-soldiers, a leggy druggie (Bond babe Olga Kurylenko) — wish she had more screen time — and a career assassin in the form of Mila Kunis. All this and more, with a dash of Blade Runner and Matrix (especially the last action sequence) and plenty of snowflakes drifting around in the constant dark backdrop.

But it's Wahlberg, the Payned anti-hero, with an expertise with the shotgun in umpteen stylised shootouts, who carries the predictable plot forward. Also notable is the film's backdrop: a drugged, psychedelic landscape spilling over with winged demons and bizarre creatures of the netherworld. And just when you thought all's well that ends well, stay tuned through the final credits -- a code that promises a sequel in the from of 'Not yet done, Max'.

Any takers? Why not... At least for the subtle message the movie passes on through fun and games: Somewhere amid the noise and the homicidal valkyries, Max Payne has a just-say-no-to-drugs message and an anti-war/terror warning that needs to be handled ASAP for 'the devil is building its army'. Anyone listening?

The film has been a winner at several international film festivals and has won the Best Film award in France. Rightly so, for The Secrets of The Grain is both cinematically and thematically mesmerising.

On the one hand is its camera work which captures the highs and lows of an immigrant French family with riveting intimacy. And on the other hand is the heartwarming story which serenades the institution of family like never before.

No homilies, no fake goodness; on the contrary, there are loads of internecine rivalries, bitching, breaking apart until the final coming together, when the head of the family actually ends up bringing the disparate members of his extended family together, even in his absence.

Sixty-year-old Silimane is a Tunisian immigrant who has been laid off from his work and decides to use his severance pay to set a restaurant that serves couscous made by his ex-wife. Currently, he is living with his mistress and his step daughter who run a seedy hotel.

Naturally, they are treated as outsiders by the rest of the family that gets together every Sunday for a family lunch, excluding them. It's a quaint ritual, meant to preserve the traditions of a family that may have become quintessentially French, yet it hasn't lost it's traditional culture.

It takes many a hurdles before Silimane's dream actually comes true. But more importantly, his couscous eatery ends up bringing the feuding Tunisian family together, despite the bitterness, the rivalries. Watch out for some excellent performances and a refreshing new look at 'family dramas.'

THE horror factory in Hollywood relentlessly keeps churning out Asian remakes, after the success of The Ring series.

This time, the devil manifests itself through malevolent mirrors, which suddenly turn murderous. Ordinary people begin to die when their reflection turns assassin and pulls jaws, cuts veins, slashes necks, or what you will.

Enter Kiefer Sutherland, a dysfunctional cop whose punishment posting now entails guarding a burnt-out building. Nothing wrong with that, except that the spooky house has a larger-than-life mirror that begins to show him strange things.

His wife dismisses it as musings of a stressed mind, but goes on high alert, when her six-year-old son too starts staring into mirrors and conversing with them. Time to go back in history and find the cause behind the mysterious apparitions.

But that doesn't matter really. What matters is the spook quotient of the film. How many times do you jump out of your seats or cover your eyes with fear?

Just two or three times, to be precise, when a reflection stares at you long after the person has moved or maybe, when it tears it's face apart with its bare hands. The rest is mostly a hunt for the missing link between illusion and reality, with lots of half-lit sequences of bloody body parts and gutturals moans.

Strictly for diehard horror buffs, Mirrors doesn't really have anything new to offer.

New York 2012. Economic recession has had many spillover effects, but this one is the least expected. Rising unemployment has resulted in a rising crime rate.

The state-run jails are bursting to the seams. Corporations are now running private prisons for profit. And they devise a novel way to make the millions flow: a televised car race amongst the prisoners that concludes only when one single participant remains alive to claim the crown.

Welcome to the new age gladiators who are mean, misfits and menacing. but the meanest of them all is the alpha girl prison warden (Joan Allen), who plays the death race with her prisoners, without a furrow on her stern brow.

In a neatly orchestrated plan, she gets a brand new racer, Jason Statham, under a false rap of murdering his wife, and reinstates him as Frankenstein, the legendary racer who died on the race tracks. The deal? Freedom and a life with his infant daughter, if he wins the bloody race which has death -- and killers -- lurking at every twisted bend.

Statham has already proved his forte as an action hero who has skilfully stepped into the shoes of Steven Segal and Jean Claude Van Demme.

His lean mean frame and his impassive face are a perfect foil to the blood and gore that bursts on screen whenever he's around. Don't ask him to talk, and he'll deliver a six-packed action punch that keeps the adrenalin pumping.

This time however, there's shades of sentiment too, since he's a dad, desperately longing to be re-united with his little daughter; a decent man who is willing to be a monster in a monstrous world.

Gritty action, good-enough drama, Death Race keeps the fun vrooming.

All sound and fury, signifying nothing new! That's the trouble with this new flick on terrorism, where once again America is in danger, with the President and his entire cabinet being the target of attack. So what's new? The nature of the attack.

This time, the terrorists chose to hit back through cyber warfare, when an American mission goes horribly wrong in the axis of evil (is it Iraq or Afghanistan? They're all faceless, bearded, turbaned terrorists in arid, uncivilised territory). They use the American supercomputer, set up for surveillance, to hijack all the cell phones, the computers, the wires, the network and force two Americans -- rebel Shia Labeouf and single mother Michelle Monaghan -- to execute their ghoulish plan.

But before they reach the White House, there's so much running around, chasing, exploding, the drama almost gets lost in action. Ironically, even the action doesn't have a cutting edge and looks jaded, much like the plot. Sad, because Shia is such a promising actor.

JAKE (Cedric the Entertainer) wakes up one morning in a hotel room with a corpse on his side. But that's the least of his problems, since he's stricken with amnesia too and ends up totally clueless in all kinds of near-death situations. So much so, he ends up thinking he's a super agent who holds a mystery chip which the whole world wants. Or is he a janitor in a video game parlour, fantasising about all the console heroes he sees on screen?

Doesn't matter, 'cause the comedy sucks, the drama is non-existent. Makes you wish you had partial amnesia too.

WRITTEN and directed by Julie Delpy, the film showcases the multi-faceted French actress in a whole new light. Specially since she manages to create an engaging urban comedy of manners that reminds you of Woody Allen's Manhattan dramas about verbally-charged, dysfunctional couples.

Jake (Adam Goldberg) and Marion (Julie Delpy) have been living together in New York for almost two years, sharing the highs, the lows and the in-betweens. Now, it's time to add some new vigour in their sagging relationship. The two take a trip to Europe and round it off in Paris, where the couple spend two days with Marion's parents and friends. Ostensibly, there are no great dramatic moments. But that doesn't matter for the film is a witty insight on emotional bonding between two culturally different people. Brimming over with delightful one-liners on clash of cultures, gender differences, sexual mores, the film is a charmer.

Watch it. It's like a breath of fresh air.

THERE'S one big problem with this 22nd Bond film. It has been severely depleted of the quantum of Bondness that made this franchise so special, so irresistible, so debonair.

No gee-whiz gadgets, no smart-ass quirps, no sardonic humour, no shaken-stirred vodka martini, no signature tune, no signature `name is Bond, James Bond' intro and no larger-than-life villain to stand up to the machismo of our invincible hero. End product? A string of hard-hitting chases and fights, where Bond gets to fly in a shaky plane, a crumbling speedboat, a sleek Aston Martin DB5, or simply on his feet.

But hey, if we need a hand-to-hand fighter who excels in hard-balled physical bouts, we'd settle for Jason Bourne rather than James Bond! For us, bred and spoiled on the Broccoli, Connery, Moore and Brosnan cult, Mr Bond is the universal soldier who saves the world without getting his tuxedo soiled, his nose hit, his shirt bloodied.

Here, Mr Craig doesn't don the tuxedo, never flashes his wry humour, is on overboil and gets all grimy in a battle that is both personal and professional. He does want to save the world's most important natural resource — water — but he also wants to avenge the death of the only woman he ever loved, Vesper Lynd in Casino Royale.

If Casino Royale was a prequel to the Bond series, then Quantum of Solace is a sequel to the film that marked the debut of Daniel Craig in the Bond series. Seething with rage after the murder of his beloved, Bond bursts on the screen in a thrilling car chase in Italy, madly pursuing a lead that would lead him to the killers. And even before you can sit back, he explodes in a hand-to-hand combat which defies all the laws of gravity.

Still waiting for a story? Impossible to understand if you haven't seen Casino Royale — you end up feeling somewhat cheated, as the secret agent sets off on some more run-ons, this time with a bronzed Olga Kurylenko as arm candy.

From Italy to Austria, Britain, Haiti, Bolivia, an unsmiling renegade Bond, with a capture-or-kill tag on his head, tries to kills two birds with a stone. He tries to stop a shady organisation, headed by Mathieu Amalric, from buying off the water source of a Bolivian township and avenge the death of Vesper too. Arm candy, Olga too has her own scores to settle with the Bolivian general who is selling off his country's resources for personal gain.

Craig's still balsy and beefcake; only a shade too embittered. The Bondettes, Olga and Gemma, are unimpressive, especially after Halle Berry had reinvented the Bond Girl with her feisty interpretation. Yet, despite the fire and brimstone, this hardly seems like a Bond film. Bring back the formula, please!

DURING World War 11, there were a number of Algerian soldiers who fought for France against the Nazis. Till today, their contribution to the cause of liberty, fraternity, equality remains mostly unacknowledged and it was only after this film that the pensions of these soldiers which had been stopped midway was reportedly resumed.

The film documents the heroism of these soldiers who may have fought shoulder to shoulder with the white men, but were denied equality. Not only were their rations and pay scale different, they were also denied promotions, despite their plea that bullets never differentiated amongst their targets in the battlefield. Their story of racism and indignity is primarily told through the experiences of four Algerian soldiers who stand up tall before the ravages of war and manage to hold on to a French town from the advancing Nazis, despite being low on ammunition and numbers. Completely denied their due, distanced from their families, the foursome continue to doggedly fight for a bunch of abstract principles...the only cause worth dying and living for.

Gritty cinema; a great message: This is Saving Private Ryan with a whole new topicality attached to it, specially when the war against terror is being fought by multi-cultural, multi-national armies made up of natives and the white man. Watch out for the stirring performances by the four lead players. The film was Algeria's official entry for Best Foreign film at the Oscars and ended up winning accolades.

TERRORIST fatigue, anyone? With almost every film taking on the terrorist these days, the viewers seem to wishing for the good old villains of yore. Guess, it will be a long wait before baddies like Dr No and Mogambo hit the screens again. Till then, happy terrorist hunting!

Now, that's not just so bad, specially when you have Leornado DiCaprio and Russell Crowe planning special operations to nab the Al Qaeda jihadis. While Crowe is the strategist, based in Washington DC, sending instructions on a cellphone, while taking his kids for basketball, DeCaprio is the action hero who enters the battlefield in the infamous axis of evil. This CIA agent is hot on the heels of Qaeda mastermind, Al-Saleem and devices a novel plan to nab the terrorist, after all measures to infiltrate the gang fail. He tries to set up a parallel terrorist network to draw out the real anarchists from their lair. But before he can do that, he must get riddled with bullets, run for his life, get bitten by diseased dogs and fall in love with a Palestinian nurse.

Clash of cultures, did we say? Nah! This nice American can not only speak Arabic, quote the Hadith, he also likes to sip tea with his Palestinian girlfriend in hostile territory. Gritty action, topical story, Body of Lies is entertaining fare.

Diesel power is on the decline. After the feisty Fast and Furious, the action hero fails to connect and kick up a storm in this futuristic film that projects him as a modern day Joseph to a mystery girl (Melanie Thierry) who has the immaculate conception.

It's a remixed biblical story that is neither here nor there, even though it takes place in the not-so-distant future, when a mean-faced Charlotte Rampling wants to start a new religion with the help of her daughter who is the potential mother of the new age messiah.

Naturally, the whole world wants to lay its evil hands on this virgin who needs a bodyguard to carry her from dangerous Russia where she lives in a convent to a not-so-dangerous New York. No prizes for guessing who is the bodyguard, specially when there is a bloated, tattooed Vin Diesel in the precincts.

He fights bombs, bullets, missiles and crosses treacherous glaciers to deliver her to safety, with some collateral damage, which includes the friendly nun, Michelle Yeoh. Amen!Tacky.

NOW why would anyone want to replace the live action histrionics of the iconic Star Wars series with strangely animated creatures who can neither capture the charisma of cult characters like Luke Skywalker, Obi Wan Kenobi, Yoda and the rest, nor can they create SFX magic of the Lucas pedigree!

Dave Filoni's animated tribute to the six-part sci-fi fantasy is another prequel that hangs somewhere between the Revenge of the Sith and The Attack of the Clones. The highlight of the film, if at all, is the confrontation between Anakin Skywalker and Count Dooku, after the evil count captures the son of Jabba the Hut and tries to put the blame on the Jedi Knights.

Why settle for second best? Watch the original, instead.

MANOJ Night Shyamalan might soon not be the only desi out there, for Bharat Nalluri has created waves with his debut venture: a wacky comedy that re-creates the 1940s in London, even as it unfolds like a sweet, lyrical fairy tale about love and ever-after.

The film traces a day in the life of Mrs Pettigrew (Frances McDormand), a woman who is hungry, friendless and minus a job as she walks through the streets of a city that is a strange contrast. On the one hand, London is quintessential Dicken's as it prepares for war and on the other, there is the gilded society that couldn't care less for the harsh realities of life. Our desperate woman seeks temporary refuge with a young singer (Amy Adams) who must practise time-management between her three suitors. More importantly, she must decide between the three and settle for love or career. Now that's not such a difficult task with the sensible Mrs Pettigrew around to tutor her. But will our delightfully destitute heroine find the love of her life too?

Why not! Believe in the fairy tale. Believe in Frances McDormand, who pitches in a perfect act. And believe in the magic of zany, unconventional storytelling.

The much-accoladed German entry in the Cannes film festival is a moving tale of humanism that transcends nationality, ethnicity and borders. Needless to say, it's an important document, loaded with lessons for our divisive times. And the fact that this story of death, loss and longing is told with marvellous restraint, only adds to its impact.

Nejat, a Turkish professor who teaches German in a German university finds his life changing after his father brings in a Turkish hooker into the house. Strangely, Nejat develops a tender bond with the woman after she tells him about her daughter in Turkey.

He sets out to find the daughter after the woman accidentally dies and ends up buying a bookstore in Istanbul, hoping to find the missing girl someday. But the girl, a political activist, has her own mission to find her mother, which leads her through circuitous paths that traverse strange places and forge uncommon bonds. This is art house cinema that is meant exclusively for cinema buffs who want to savour new wave delights.

He's six feet five inches tall, red in colour, sports a tail, is mostly angry, has a love interest, was born in a Nazi-sponsored petri dish, but now works for the US government as the reluctant superhero in the Bureau of Paranormal Research and Defence.

That's the comic book hero Hellboy for you, who has his second outing under Guillermo Del Toro's creative expertise, and ends up better than his first avtar. Del Toro had already grabbed eyeballs with his visually innovative film, Pan's Labyrinth, which created enough buzz at the Oscars. Here, his fascination for the supra-normal, the bizarre and the beyond-imagination creatures gets free flow, as he sculpts the immortal good versus evil clash with an outlandish superguy and a horde of trolls, elves, goblins.

Hellboy's army comprises his pyrokinetic girlfriend, Liz Sherman (Selma Blair), his fishman buddy, Abe Sapien (Doug Jones) and the ectoplasmic rookie, Johann Kraus (James Donn). The bunch of brave weirdoes are out to quell the Golden Army: swarming hordes of killing machines led by the evil elf, Prince Nuada (Luke Gross) who dreams of world domination.

Get dizzy on the special effects and the unbounded creativity of a director who blends the aesthetics and the mythology of Star Wars and Lord of the Rings with Japanese manga.

You'll find adequate `boos' in this film to give you your money's worth. Of course, you might end up feeling scared behind the closed comfort of your fortified homes, but that really doesn't matter. Because this one's a neat little chiller that creates fear out of the familiar: dark corners in the room, peepholes that show masked figures, walls that are incessantly battered with loud knocks, glass panes that reflect strange images.

Liv Tyler and Scott Speedman return from the woods to their home and hope to resolve an unfinished quarrel before the night is over. But the night stretches into infinity and the little domestic tiff pales into the shadows as the duo are threatened by three strange, masked figures who threaten to break into their house, for no reason at all.

With his hand held camera and his jump cuts, the debutant director manages to create a smart horror flick.

Scully and Mulder are back. And the good news is they haven't lost their chutzpah. The unsmiling duo who was seriously serious about E.T. and other para-normal stuff, return to encounter one more bizarre tryst, as the FBI battles with the disappearance of its agents. And the heroes deliver once again, with enough punch to please all the X-philes out there.

Of course, they begin reluctantly, since both have left the FBI and tried to begin anew, seeking normalcy in an abnormal world. While Scully is a doctor, battling with inexplicable diseases, Mulder has faded into oblivion, still haunted by the memory of his sister who was abducted by E.T.

The FBI solicits their help in tracking a serial killer after their agent vanishes into the blue and a psychic priest has visions about her abductor. It doesn't take long before the non-believers become believers. Both Scully and Mulder end up in hot pursuit of a maniac who is on the brink of conducting one of the most hair-raising experiments in medical surgery. Watch it for its gripping narrative and chilling climax.

HOW do families cope with secrets and lies? Do they break up or are familial bonds stronger than adversity? That's the compelling dilemma in this stark, moody documentation of a close-knit Turkish family that is suddenly in disarray when the head of the family ends up in prison, taking the rap for his employer's misdemeanours for the sake of money. While the son prefers to spend his time sleeping, completely losing his focus, the wife tries her best to cope up. Expediency forces her into a relationship with the man who sent her husband to prison and the situation threatens to blow out of control when the husband returns.

This is Turkish cinema at its innovative best. Do not miss.

THIS one's vulgar, zany, funny, almost a laugh riot, with the most topical message of all. It resolves the Israel-Palestinian conflict with it's schmaltzy love story between the Mossad counter-terrorist, Zohan (Adam Sandler) and the delightful Palestinian hair dresser, Dalia (Emmanuelle Chriqui).

The hero of the show is obviously Adam Sandler with his swollen crotch that seems to have a life of its own, his Arab English, his action hero tactics, his distaste for hate and his desire for world peace. He runs away from a mission, aimed at capturing Phantom, the most powerful Palestinian `terrorist', flees to America and tries to fulfil his dream of becoming a hair stylist. Of course, he sheds his identity of the mighty Zohan and becomes Scrappy Coco, the favourite barber of all the bored women in Manhattan who end up getting more bang for their buck. In between, he falls in love with his employer, the beautiful Palestinian woman, and tries to put an end to the world's most pressing problem, The Arab-Israel conflict, with a hose pipe full of humus.

Reminiscent of Borat's cross cultural misadventures, this is one of Adam Sandler's funniest comedies.

Al Pacino and Robert DeNiro have created screen magic whenever they have come together. Remember Heat and The Godfather ll?

The magical chemistry is still there as the two veterans play NYPD cops who are trying to nab a psycopath; but age does seem to be catching up with two of Hollywood's greatest.

The duo have partenered each other successfully for several years in the crime-infested streets of New York. Now, one of the them (Robert DeNiro) is under suspicion by his own department, since most of the victims of the serial murders seem to have some connection with his past.

While partner Pacino is willing to go out of his way to save his buddy, he must contend with internecine hostility, as a bunch of rivals cops try their best to nail the invincible twosome.

Watch out for the hard-hitting climax, where Pacino displays his powerhouse histrionics, while DeNiro stands up, rock firm and solid.

The Devil gives up not only her Prada, but also her devilish ways and becomes a singing, dancing angelic muse in this breezy musical that lightens your heart and puts a song to your lips.

Yes, Meryl Streep does a complete makeover here, as the wild and ebullient mother of a young bride-to-be (Amanda Seyfried) who invites her mother's three boyfriends to her wedding.

movie

Wanna get a lo-down on the sleaze that's part and parcel of Manhattan's upper crust? Watch Deception.

Ewan McGregor, an accountant meets a mysterious lawyer, Hugh Jackman, smokes pot with him and ends up joining an equally mysterious club of upmarket singletons who believe in the credo `intimacy without intricacy.'

But the simpleton accountant can't seem to follow the rules and loses his heart to a delicious blonde. So what if that's the beginning of a tryst with death and deception? Love does conquer all, doesn't it?

THIS Spanish film with English subtitles takes a gritty look at the underbelly of the American Dream through the eyes of two Mexican immigrants who end up in New York, in search of El dorado.

On their way to Brooklyn, Juan steals the bag, and the identity, of the friendly Pedro who is on his way to seek out his father, a restaurateur in New York. Juan poses as Pedro and ends up with the father, hoping to steal his money, while hungry and desperate Pedro, teams up with a druggie, hoping to find his dad, someday. And all along, there is the threat of being deported which adds to their immigrant woes.

The film takes you on a journey through New York, like never before, where the glitter has been replaced by the grime; the hope by despair. Powerful cinema.

THIS one's a delicious rom com that has you smiling and grinning with its rib-tickling battle of the sexes that rages on and on....Until the waves begin to break, the stars begin to shine.
Ashton Kutcher is the archetypal loser who can't hold on to his job, even when he works for his dad. Cameron Diaz is the kick-ass Wall Street analyst who ends up getting dumped by her I-me-myself boyfriend. The depressed duo meet in Vegas, get drunk, get married, win a million dollar lottery and realise they must remain married for six months at least, if they want a share of the prize money. Obviously, an impossible task, specially when Kutcher has awful toilet habits and Cameron is a stickler for neatness and niceties. But in the midst of their bickering and brawl, it's the marriage counsellor who actually hits the nail on head: Individually, they are atrocious; together they are super!

A breezy comedy, the film crackles with some great chemistry between the lead pair and makes merry with the evergreen theme of Martian men and Venus women battling it out for equilibrium and ever after.

NOW this one's a powerful warning to mankind, even as it is perfectly entertaining cinema. It's the 22nd century. Planet Earth has been reduced to a wasteland where there are only mounds of rubbish being regurgitated into kachra skyscrapers by the sole inhabitant: a diligent robot called Wall-E. Humans have slipped off the globe into a robotic haven and have metamorphosed into fat, sluggish no-gooders, leading a life of obscene mechanised luxury. It's left to the rusty, clunky Wall-E to rediscover the values of love, life and bonding while he leads his solitary life on a desolate planet that suddenly sprouts its first sapling, after centuries of decay.

movie

James McAvoy is the world's favourite punching bag, leading a desultory life, until one day he is abducted by a mysterious and sizzling Angelina Jolie and taken for a ride of his life. Life's never the same for this archetypal loser who suddenly discovers he is the best shooter in the world and is inducted into the Fraternity, a special organisation that kills all potential killers after their names are woven into a strange machine called the loom of life.

Watch the film for its high-testosterone stunts and action sequences, although Jolie fans might end up somewhat disappointed by this outing.

TWO women and a man thrown together in the inhospitable Arctic Tundra can create some compelling drama. Specially since there's a shortage of both food and love.

Michelle Yeoh is a woman who has been branded as cursed. She does find love but loses it, when her entire community, including her husband, is killed by a bunch of marauders. She flees into the cold with the lone survivor, a baby girl, and brings her up as her daughter, teaching her to trust no one.

But the uneasy equilibrium between the two suddenly veers into dangerous territory when she finds a man (Sean Bean) dying in the snow. She brings him home, only to realise that he's the bone of contention now, with both the mother and daughter vying for his attention. The cold threatens to envelop her further when she learns the duo are all set to leave her soon. It isn't the waters alone that begin to freeze; her heart begins to turn cold too. Time for some bone-chilling action....

Asif Kapadia who made an impressive debut with The Warriors, does try to re-create another art house experience with Far North. Watch it for its awesome cinematography and for the hard-hitting climax.

IT can't get more scary than Carrie, can it? Speaking of prom nights and all the films that feature it Carrie remains the most memorable film, with the tele-kinetic teenager's nightmare still creating a chill amongst film buffs.

This film too seems to be a re-make of John Carpenter's 1980s Halloween, but the chill factor has been completely diluted, although there's the usual body count, as Britanny Snow's prom night gets tainted with blood and gore.

High School senior, Donna Keppel (Brittany) has been trying to rebuild her life after a psychotic teacher killed her entire family, simply because he wanted her for just for himself. But her tragic past begins to haunt her prom night, with the killer having escaped from the maximum security asylum and choosing to hunt her down again.

It's a lack lustre film that evokes a sense of deja vu, specially in an age when slasher films are so outdated.

GUSTY guys, pretty girls, awesome planes and speed-of-lightning aerial antics: anything more that AXN buffs could ask for? Billed as a French Top Gun, the film keeps the adrenalin pumping with its tale of two fighter pilots, Walk'n and Fahrenheit, who end up saving Paris on Bastille Day from a bunch of terrorists who have stolen a Mirage and propose to create havoc with the flying machine. Of course, our heroes are unflappable and cannot be put down by anything, neither terrorists nor by a hostile terrain where they have been forced to land when an air show goes awry.

Fasten your seat belts and let the high testosterone pyrotechnics take over your senses. The director reportedly mounted four 35mm cameras on a Mirage 2000 to capture the aerial high drama.

Hollywood too has its canned films. Like some of Bollywood's moth-balled movies, actor Alec Baldwin's directorial venture had been lying half-baked for quite some time before finding a theatrical release in the US. The effect shows, for this Faustian bargain -- Baldwin sells his soul to devil, Jennifer Love Hewitt, lacks the sting of a delightfully devilish tale.

Baldwin plays a struggling writer who sells his soul to the devil in a trenchcoat and ends up with the spoils of success -- money, fame, women....But soul satisfaction is what he lacks. He goes hunting for orator Daniel Webster (Anthony Hopkins) who promises to win back his soul in a supra-natural trial against the She-Devil.

Watch it if you must, but only for Anthony Hopkins.

Mummy slayer Richard O'Connor (Brendan Fraser) has been in blissful retirement after sending off Imoteph to his grave forever in Mummy 1 and 2. Blissful, did we say? Bored would be a better word, as the explorer tries to while away his time in Mummy 3, shooting fish, while wife Evelyn (Maria Bello) wistfully dreams of writing her third book on the Mummy adventures. Even their twenty-something son (Luke Ford) seemed to have abandoned their dour company, preferring to join his uncle in distant Shanghai, excavating treasures on his own.

movie

DAN Burns (Steve Carell) is a popular newspaper columnist who writes a family advice column but has a million family problems of his own.

A widower, he has been trying his best to bring up his three teenage daughters all by himself, even as he shoots off homilies on family bondings to his readers. Indeed, a tough task which gets even tougher when he takes his girls for a family reunion on Thanksgiving to his parent's (Diane Wiest and John Mahoney) rambling house in Rhode Island.

He walks into a bookstore and meets the delectable Marie (Juliette Binoche) who seems to be his soul mate, but for her boyfriend. Trouble grows tenfold when sweet Marie walks in for the family reunion too, since she's almost family. Her boyfriend happens to be desperate Dan's brother!

Sweet and witty, the film makes for pleasant viewing.

Holy smoke! Batman may be the Dark Knight, but guess who's the Shining Knight who steals the show away from the super-hero? He's none other than the super-villain, the manic, irrepressible, jaw-dropping Joker. Yes, Heath Ledger pitches in a breath-taking performance as Batman's arch rival in Christopher Nolan's breath-taking renditition of the comic book hero's second caper after Batman Begins. It wouldn't be wrong to say that Ledger's Joker is even more mesmerising than Jack Nicholson's Joker in the 1989 film, Batman. Nor would it be wrong to salute Nolan for bridging the gap between pop art and pure art with this high-energy, explosive battle of good versus evil.

movie

BASED on the controversial book by prison guard James Gregory, Goodbye Bafana traces his relationship with Nelson Mandela that covers a span of almost two decades. The film focuses on the transformation that the racist Gregory (Joseph Fiennes) undergoes after coming in contact with the South African leader. While Joseph Fiennes renders a sensitive performance of a racist-in-reform, Dennis Haysbert fails to create the charisma of Mandela on screen. But the legend of Mandela carries the film forward, even as director Bille August creates a moving biograph of a hero.

IT'S a drama of love, passion and desertion set against the backdrop of the Tudor period, where a brooding King Henry V111 (Eric Bana) is desperate to have a male heir for the throne of England.

When his wife fails to give him a son, he loses interest in her and finds himself being drawn towards two sisters, Mary and Anne Boleyn (Scarlett Johansson and Natalie Portman), in that order.

The sisters are basically used as pawns by their ambitious father, but Anne, the elder doesn't really mind and ends up marrying the King and changing the course of England's history by forcing him to break with the Catholic Church. Mary, the elder, is gentler, kinder and truly loves the King. But kindness doesn't take you very far amidst court intrigue.

She ends up as the abandoned mistress of the king and spends the rest of her life in the countryside, with her illegitimate son.

It's a lush period drama with the usual underpinnings of greed, lust and deceit.

HE says he's not a big fat panda. He's THE Big Fat Panda! True. Salutations to one of the sweetest, funniest animation hero to be seen on the screen, of late. Big, bumbling, belly-dancing Po is the most unlikely hero you can think of.

And yet, in his heroism lies the secret of everyman's heroism. Po tells us that anybody can be a hero, because there is no special, secret ingredient. Neither for the noodles that he and his father make nor for the spirit it takes to defeat the evil Kung Fu renegade, the treachorus Tai Lung.

Po (Jack Black) has been living with his father selling noodle soup for all these years. The only bright spot in his banal life is his obsession for Kung Fu and his fan worship for the current Kung Fu masters: Tigress (Angelina Jolie), Viper, Mantis, Monkey (Jackie Chan) and Crane.

Life takes a somersault when he crash lands into the ceremony where the wise turtle is selecting the new hero who will take on the villainous snow leopard, Tai Lung who has escaped from prison. The turtle selects Po and leaves the aging Kung Fu Master Shifu (Dustin Hoffman) to train him for the final duel. Can Shifu believe in the clumsy panda? Can the clumsy panda believe in himself? Can a commoner be a hero?

Great visuals, excellent animation, a sassy script and a story that appeals to all: Kung Fu Panda is truly a new age parable on heroism.

IT'S the season of super heroes in Hollywood. Close on the heels of Iron Man, Indiana Jones and The Incredible Hulk comes Hancock, to be followed by Hellboy and Batman. But hey, John Hancock is the most unconventional of them all with his dramatic tale of what it costs the world to have a super hero, a super cop, a super saviour. For, though Hancock may save the struggling whale, men and women held hostage by unreasonable killers, potential victims of an accident, he does leave a trail of destruction behind, causing a lot of super normal people to curse him for his super skills.

It isn't difficult to read Hancock's true story. The world bashing of the super hero, who gets criticised for saving the world, is actually a parable for post 9/11 America. Think of the trail of destruction it left behind in Afghanistan, Iraq, even as it claimed to rid the world of terrorists; think of the ungrateful world which hurled abuses at it instead of saying ‘thank you' and you'll realise that like super hero Hancock, super power America too simply needs some good PR to set its image right.

Enter Jason Bateman, the benevolent public relations man who wants to change the world. Having been saved by the alcoholic, abusive Hancock, he realises that the hero is just a victim of bad PR. He offers to take him on as his client, gives him a shiny black super hero suit to work in, instead of his grubby overalls, convinces him to shave off his stubble with his nails, enter the scene of action through the door instead of breaking down walls, and more importantly, learn to say ‘Good Job!' to the beleagured cops who have been trying so hard before him. Hancock tries to give up his brutish ways and become a gentleman superman, but there's the beautiful and mysterious superwoman (Charlize Theron) who makes excellent meat balls when she's not taking her son to soccer matches.

It's completely zany, this 800 year-old love story between the superman and the superwoman, even as Will Smith creates absolute hungama with his anti-hero heroics. Hear him introduce himself to his support group in the prison: 'I'm Hancock. I drink and all that stuff!' Great fun.

SIT back, Sarah Jessica Parker. Here's a Lebanese take on Sex and the City which captures the lives of a bunch of women in Beirut, as they struggle to find love and happiness.

Most of the drama takes place in a beauty salon in a busy street and revolves around the women who run it. While Layale (Nadine Labaki) is embroiled in an anguish-ridden affair with a married man, Nisrine (Yasmine Al Masri) needs to take care of her lost virginity before she marries an orthodox Muslim. Rima, the third partner, struggles between her confused sexuality and finds herself being irresistibly drawn towards a beautiful customer who walks in for a shampoo. Add to this two old sisters, left to fend for each other, an American who likes to wear his trousers short and a caramel-hearted cop, and you have a delicious cocktail of love, longing and feminism.

Exotica. Don't miss it.

HOLLYWOOD is determined to cash on the charisma of tele-hearthrob, Patrick Dempsey who has successfully managed to emerge as a romantic hero after his stint in Grey's Anatomy. He is the new age Mr McDreamy who has already displayed his dream lover skills in Enchanted, Hollywood's delightful retelling of the Snow White story. Here, he attempts another Adonis-revisited tale which too is a take two of an earlier breezy Hollywood romance, My Best Friend's Wedding. Dempsey steps into the delectable shoes of the beautiful Ms Julia Roberts who was hell bent on sabotaging her buddy's impending marriage, once she discovered he was her groom material.

This time round, it's Dempsey, the millionaire playboy of Manhattan, who has two weeks to destroy, best friend Hannah's (Michelle Monaghan) wedding with a bloke (Kevin McKidd) she found on a business trip, only because he thinks his best friend is bride material. The film actually begins with a prologue where Dempsey is the college Romeo Tom who ends up mistakenly in firebrand Hannah's bed, only to be subjected to some smart talk which sees the two ending up as soul mates rather than bed mates. Soon, Tom is a millionaire with a million conquests in bed, but the ability to say `I love you' only to canines, while Hannah is a serious career woman who laughs fondly at her buddies sexual mores. She goes on a business trip to Scotland and the metamorphosis begins. Tom realises he loves her and waits for her to return to break the good news. But all he can do is watch his heart break, when Hannah returns with a beau in tow and a wedding round the corner.

The rest is all fun and games as Tom tries his best to sabotage his best friend's marriage plans, even though she wants him to be her maid of honor. The chemistry may be a bit tepid and the plot somewhat tardy and foregone, but there's enough for Dempsey fans to get dreamy about.

LONG years ago, it was Holden Caulfield who was thrown out of an upmarket prep school to end up as an iconic teen hero in J.D. Salinger's Catcher in the Rye. Seventeen-year-old Charlie Bartlett (Anton Yelchin) is a worthy heir to Caulfield's rebellious teen angst in this sassy and smart teen comedy that brings back the dysfunctional 1970s-1980s, when teenagers hadn't yet transmuted into the well-adjusted I-pod generation.

Charlie (Anton Yelchin), a poor little rich kid, is thrown out of almost all the private schools, much to the discomfiture of his single mother (Hope Davis) who is forced to send him to the neighbourhood public school.

Naturally, Charlie, in his shirt and tie, is a total misfit in the plebeaen environs and ends up bearing the brunt of the school bully on his first day at school. But Charlie is a survivor and soon ends up the most popular guy on campus, donning the cap of the in-house shrink who offers a pill for every solution. Having been prescribed Ritalin by his own shrink, he begins dispensing them to all his peers suffering from low esteem, heart-break, popularity craze....School's a rollercoaster ride, but for the perceptive principal (Robert Downey Jr) and his irresistible daughter (Kat Denning) who finds Charlie alluring too.

Compelling performances by Robert Downey Jr and Anton Yelchin coupled with an undercurrent of comedy make this an interesting film that mirrors high school life with all its highs and lows.

THE film has been hailed at the festival circuit and been toasted at Cannes too.

And rightly so, for here's a whole new style -- and content -- for animation.

It traces the attempt's of an Iranian woman to seek out her identity against the tumultuous history (1970 onwards) of her country.

Marjane, the protagonist sees her country passing from one misrule to another, sometimes from the distance and sometimes from the midst of all the action itself.

It's a fervent call for liberalism, the independence of women and democracy in a film that uses history as a fascinating backdrop, despite its contemporaniety.

Absolutely exquisite fare.

NOW this one's quite a funny spoof on the James Bond series, in league with Austin Powers' ass-brained mission to save the world.

Maxwell Smart (Steve Carell) is the most unusual super agent who gets his chance to save the American President -- and the world -- from a nuke attack, on his first field assignment.

Of course, he has his distractions in the form of his svelte partner, Agent 99 (Anne Hathaway) who kicks butt and creates a storm with her super skills.

Add to this, the double crossing Dwayne Johnson and a buffoonish American Prez, and you have a smart comedy that makes time fly.

ANG Lee's tryst with this lesser-known Marvel superhero didn't really scorch the screens a few years ago. This time, Eric Bana has been replaced by Edward Norton in the eponymous role and the film has been directed by a director known for his action films (Transporter 2). Does it work? Only slightly better, even though the director puts two giants in his film, good guy Hulk and bad guy Abomination.

Norton's choice to play the title role is quite apt, because he's quite unnoticeable in his normal state. As a simple worker in a factory in Guatemala, he tries to find a cure for the gamma radiation that has altered his DNA. But before he can contact his online benefactor, the ruthless American general wants to capture him, replicate his blood group and create hundreds of Hulks who would serve as loyal American soldiers in all its sundry battlefields, the world over. Naturally, this is too much excitement for our superhero who can't even make love, in case his pumping adrenalin turns him into the green monster. So, with all those flying missiles and tanks, he simply turns mad.

But Hulk is actually a hero and turns from fugitive to grand patriot, as he battles the other genetically-engineered product of the US army, the Abomination. All this action-hero stuff takes place, even his beloved (Liv Tyler) wants him to simply settle down as Bruce Banner, the inconsequential boyfriend who would have passed unnoticed through life.

Enough action to keep the popcorn crackling, The Hulk has an added attraction: a guest appearance by Iron Man, basking in his newfound success.

GREEN turns mean. Really mean. Yet, somehow, this Nature-Strikes-Back venture from Shyamalan may be a forceful plea to save the environment and keep your carbon footprint really small, it isn't great cinema. In fact, the chill quotient is so low that you almost wonder whether Shyamalan is actually a Hitchkockian heir. Although we would not like to write him off as a one-film wonder, we do confess there isn't anything -- neither the shock and awe factor nor the emotional quotient -- of The Sixth Sense in The Happening. You don't walk out looking tentatively at the trees nor skirting the bushes around you, even though the director has tried his best to invest them with a menacing life of their own. Not like when you began to take a second look at the friendly feathered forms after watching a DVD of Alfred Hitchcock's The Birds, a film which seems to have inspired this film.

In terms of topicality, Shyamalan however scores. The film opens with a horrific morning in Central Park when New York is struck by a deadly virus that causes people to commit suicide. As soon as a mysterious breeze begins to blow, people in the park and the street begin to shoot themselves, workers jump off high rise buildings, zoo strollers put their hands and heads in the lion's mouth, glass shreds are used to slash wrists, ropes are meant for hanging.... Yes, no one's safe, not anywhere, for soon the virus spreads to the small towns as well and forces a science teacher (Mark Wahlberg) and his estranged wife (Zooey Deschanel) to join the mass exodus, with a father (John Leguizamo) and his eight-year-old daughter.

It's basically a road movie, with the invisible killer virus chasing the bunch of hapless people who kill themselves gradually, while the nation looks for answers. Shyamalan offers no concrete answers, nor does he make you jump out of your seats. All he suggests is the possibility of nature wreaking its vengeance against a human race that has filled the air with toxins. The trees, bushes and grass have grown extra sensitive and are sending out strange emissions too. So much so, you have an almost demented scientist (Wahlberg) talking to a plant, only to find out it is plastic.

Shyamalan tries to pitch an Al Gorian hypothesis in Hitchkockian style. But unfortunately, his open-ended film leaves too many questions unanswered and has too few twists to thrill the viewer.

THIS may not be as good as Gondry's seminal sci-fi romance, Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. But for Gondry fans, who got hooked on to him after his first film, this one's not to be missed.

Be Kind Rewind is the name of the rundown video store in a rundown neighbourhood in New Jersey. The store is soon to be pulled down to give way to a glitzy new condominium, much to the discomfiture of its owner Danny Glover who goes on a trip to find ways to salvage his shrinking business. While he's snooping around at the successful West Coast Video store, he leaves his shop to his assistant (Mos Def) who's best friend (Jack Black) ends up almost annihilating the store in his absence. Due to some quirky accident, the friend manages to erase all the tapes and the only way they can save the business is by re-shooting the films, their own way. They begin by creating their own version of Ghostbusters which ironically becomes a hit. Soon, the whole neighbourhood is queuing up for the indigenous versions of Hollywood blockbusters, which includes Robocop armed with a hair dryer.

Funny, whimsical and warm, the film also raises the flag for the underdogs. And for indie cinema.

The popular television series finally finds its way to the big screen. And thank God for it. For this modern fairy tale about four women and their misadventures about love and longing is witty, lively and strikes an instant chord with all those cosmosexuals out there who are struggling with their own EQ and its quixotic demands.
