INDY is back and E.T. is angry. What more could you fantasy guzzlers ask for! Let your imagination run riot as giant ants hungrily gobble up humans, young Shia LaBeouf does a dazzling round of sword fencing with catwoman Cate Blanchett, while he is precariously balanced on two speeding jeeps, Harrison Ford lead his family through an ancient archeological maze, peopled with strange tribals, Karen Allen drive them down three never-ending rapids, without losing her hold on the steering wheel and the old lovers squabbling in the middle of a bog, with a rat snake to rescue them. And if that's not nail-biting stuff, then how about thirteen E.T.s staying back on Earth, teaching man the marvels of technology, building a fabled kingdom of gold, long, long ago...and finally losing their cool, when someone steals one of their crystal skulls and curious Cate -- a Russian agent -- wants to steal their knowledge. And hey, there are the emotional bits too that anchor the action in evergreen family kitsch. Like, Dad Indy and son Mutt (Shia LaBeouf) sharing milkshake in a cafe or racing on a mobike, right into the college library, while the Russians are gunning for them.

It's a great comeback for the quintessential adventurer, Henry Jones Junior (Harrison Ford) who may be 65 years old, but he is still not willing to relinquish his characteristic hat to Henry Jones Junior 11. More importantly, he's still agile enough to save the archeological wonders that lie outside the arid classrooms where he teaches and even walks down the aisle with his old flame Marion Ravenwood (Karen Allen), while his son smiles down at him and combs his carefully cultivated puff with panache.

Yes, style is the buzzword here, where the winning combination of George Lucas and Steven Spielberg recreate the splendour of the other three Indiana Jones films. Needless to say, Indy fans will always remember Raiders of the Lost Ark as their favourite in this quartet and will find the fourth a trifle slow. It does take some time for the adventure to warm up as Indiana Jones tries to outdo the evil Russians, headed by a deliciously malevolent Cate Blanchett, in finding the missing kingdom of gold founded by crystal-bodied aliens. Jones is helped by his wife, son and a senile professor who accompany him to the forbidden land in an adventure that combines Spielberg's two great passions: his love for larger-than-life special effects and his fascination for extra-terrestrials.

Harrison Ford is like vintage wine, getting more heady as he greys and wrinkles ups. And along with young LaBeouf, he makes a winsome pair. Watch winsome LaBeouf turn up his nose at him and ask: how old are you anyway? Eighty-five? Then, watch our old man teach the kid lessons he can never pick up in school.

IT'S a quirky road trip across the Indian heartland which presents colourful vignettes of a country which is being increasingly viewed as the perfect spa for soul therapy by the West. Director Wes Anderson captures the colours, smells and motifs of spiritual and mofussil India in this tale of three brothers who journey through India to discover themselves.

Refreshingly, the style isn't as heavy as the theme may sound. For this sojourn of re-connecting with self and family is full of zany moments, which include an overdose of cough syrup, an attack of pepper spray, a tryst with a cobra, sex with the train stewardess, a sombre funeral attendance, replete with the colours and sounds of a camera that looks at India as the archetypal Exotic East.

Owen Wilson invites his two brothers, Adrian Brody and Jason Schwartzman for a trip to India for two reasons. First he wants to find their mother (Angelica Huston) who had abandoned the family in America and disappeared into the Himalayas. And secondly, he wants the dysfunctional family to reconnect once again and heal the wounds that had been inflicted by time. The three brothers have their own sorrowful histories. While one is running away from fatherhood, the other is nursing a broken heart. They undertake the journey reluctantly, only to realise that this is one trip they would never like to end.

Hey, didn't we say, east or west, India is the best! Jokes apart, this trip is recommended for its quirky quotient.

The Pevensie kids are back, playing kings and queens, despite being tweens and teens. After having entered the fabled land through their wooden cupboard and battled the White Witch (Tilda Swinton) in the first part, they return after 1,300 years to their favourite kingdom, this time through the London tube. Once again, it's left to the fierce foursome to reinstate order and justice in a land torn by a bitter war of attrition between an evil king and his nephew, the true heir to the throne.

IT grabs your eyeballs from the word Go and never lets go, till the final race is run, the victory lap is done, the family ties are strengthened and the spirit of freedom celebrated. Yes, Speed Racer is a film that breaks all the stereotypes, even though it dabbles with nothing but stereotypes. Based on a Japanese cartoon, the film blends all the popular elements of mainstream cinema -- action, family drama, David versus Goliath -- and produces a heady cocktail that literally makes your head turn. Not so much by the story -- you've seen it so many times, you already know all the twists and turns -- as much by its style. The Wachowski brothers have indeed created a whole new Matrix for cinema by replacing reality for a computer-generated, manga-like backdrop that looks straight out of an Andy Warhol painting. The colours are a giddy orange, yellow and purple; the landscape is psychedelic and surreal; the action is gravity-defying and jaw-dropping...

And the drama? So very conventional. So very topical. The Racer family is the archetypal happy family which lives on love, fresh air and milk, despite the fact that it has a tradition of victory behind it. The Racer sons are natural born racers who have been hogging the headlines for long, while racing the home-made cars manufactured by Pops (John Goodman). Trouble begins when Rex Racer, the eldest son loses a race and supposedly dies in a crash. Speed (Emile Hirsch), the second son, now dons the mantle and begins winning again, much to the discomfiture of the automative magnate (Roger Allam) who wants to buy him up and become his sponsor. But for the fiercely independent -- and highly talented -- Racer family, the sponsor is viewed as the devil and Speed tries his best to win the Grand Prix all by himself, even though the Buy-it-all honcho insists all the races are fixed.

While the family bonding scenes, specially the pep talk between Speed and Pops and Speed and Mom (Susan Sarandon) tug at your heart, it's the races that thrust you into playstation gear and get your adrenaline pumping. But more than all this, it is the structure and the anime form of the film which completely dazzles you. And the fact that all this tussle between big money and the basic spirit of the game happens in IPl season only makes the film extremely topical. Don't miss this post-modern pulp fiction.

THERE'S got to be magic when two maestros meet. And there is. The Forbidden Kingdom creates moments of high action and fun when the champions of chopsucky, Jackie Chan and Jet Li, clash in this quaint oriental tale that takes you back to ancient China, when warriors ruled, monks fought and Monkey Kings metamorphosed into stone. And to ensure you don't lose yourself in this high testosterone time machine, there's our teen hero, an American kid who spends his time watching old Kung Fu videos from the local pawn shop, to keep you grounded.

The drama is almost relentless, from the time the kid enters the pawn shop to discover the antique mast and listen to the mumbo-jumbo of the old Chinese shopkeeper. It's the mast that catapults him back in time, since it has to be returned to its rightful owner, the Monkey King. And the only two people who can help him reach his destination, an inhospitable place at a mountain top, is a drunken beggar (Jackie Chan) and a silent monk (Jet Li). Needless to say, the super duo is enough to stave off an entire army sent by the evil warrior who covets the mast and sends a delectable witch in hot pursuit.

Zany, funny, racy, the film has the flavour of Jackie Chan films and the action of Jet Li thrillers.

Iron man may not have been the Big Hero of Marvel Comics, but here, in his first film avtar, he stands as tall as the rest of masked crusaders. And the fact that he talks about contemporary problems -- de-militarisation, end of war -- only makes him more alluring. Iron Man's Big No to weapons of mass destruction makes all the more sense because it comes from a man who is supposed to be the largest manufacturer of WMDs that are creating havoc, the world over. Makes you hope that someday, all the Tony Starks (that's his true identity) of the world will actually sing Bob Dylan's Blowin' in the Wind.

SO, yet motionless bodies moving our way and passionate kisses turning into chocking coughs? Now, haven't we seen that before? And with Shutter and its theme of spirit photography, we surely seem to have lost count. The film coughs up another vengeful ghost who tries to get her message across as many ghosts have done in the past. However, her ways are quite indirect and static. Not just atmosphere, the film lacks tension, wit and the much-needed scares. Even the storyline has another case of blurred images in bathroom mirrors, characters waking up from awful dreams, nothing new to offer. Newly wed wife joins her fashion shutterbug husband on his work tour to Japan, gets to see a whole lot of fashionably dressed semi-clad models, interacts with the who's who of fashion industry, till she finally discovers she's being followed by a ghost. And who helps her know that? Believe it or not, the husband's shutter, aka camera, that clicks pictures of the spirit under the table, on the bed, in the bathroom, on the roof, in the terrace, in the restaurant, at the wedding reception... And if that's not all, in the end, on the shoulders of the hero! A reason to shudder... oops shutter? ? ?

BASED on a Hong Kong horror film, The Eye comes a wee bit late. Because, Bollywood has already ripped it. Remember Naina, where Urmila Matondkar saw stuff - death, accidents, ghosts - after a cornea transplant. Replace Ms Matondkar with Jessica Alba and the soporific horror sequences of the B-grade Bollywood film with a handful of real chills and thrills and rest assured: this is an adequate time-pass film.

Alba is Sydney Wells, the young, blind musician, who goes in for a cornea transplant, only to discover she was better off without sight. For her blurry vision shows her dead and dying people along with the shadowy, skeletal angels of death. More scary is the image she sees in the mirror in place of her face. It's a sad, doleful girl who seems to be telling her something. All that Alba has to do is to ferret that girl out and find out the disasters that lie in wait. And the only person who can help her is the reluctant doctor who drives her all the way to Mexico to meet her donor.

Not the best for Alba fans, nevertheless there's ample fun for horror buffs here.

Based on the best-selling series of books, The Spiderwick Chronicles is perfect summer fare for kids. It's got adventure, goblins, monsters, fairies and magic too: stuff that's been patented as Potted lexicon, even though it came long before.

OKAY, so this is supposedly a kiddie flick, but we'd recommend it for adults too. Simply because it has subliminal messages for the lean-mean adult world.

Horton, the friendly elephant who likes to wear his ears like a punk's cap, suddenly hears a voice from a speck of dust that flits across his ears. He stops romping in the forest greens and takes a moment to listen. Is somebody out there, he yells. And gets a response too: from the Mayor of Whoville, a land where nothing goes wrong. It never has, it never will. Or so believe the happy-go-lucky Whovilles, until their world is threatened by the super-powered jungle folk, lead by the Lady Kangaroo who thinks Horton is lying. How can a speck of dust encapsulate a whole world, she chides the sensitive elephant and tries to devour the clover which holds the speck. It takes a lot of trumpeting and tail-pulling from Horton and his bunch of crusader friends to teach the arrogant kangaroo a lesson meant for all: Everyone's important, no matter how small.

Get the general drift? Yup, this one's a sweet little parable on politics with its cutesy diatribe against big worlds swallowing small worlds. Go for it.

A jelly bean of a film, this one looks at 9/ll - and the acrimonious aftermath - through sugar-coated glasses. Nevertheless, you are willing to forgive the childlike simplicity of the director's attempts to dissect complicated conundrums like racial prejudice, communal bias, only because it states its message so very simply. The pithy film celebrates the spirit of tolerance, humaneness and empathy without going into heavy-handed dissertations on terror, Islam, jehad, backlash....

The spirit of the film belongs to Anupam Kher who essays the role of a Sikh Colonel who heads a happy Hindustani family in Manhattan. Come 9/11 it isn't only the WTC Towers that end up as debris. The Colonel loses his son (Vikram Chatwal) in the terrorist attack and has no one to vent his anger on, other than Ali (Amit Sial), a young photographer who has befriended the family. Spending lonely hours in police stations and pubs, trying to find a rationale behind the gnawing sense of loss, he finds a soft target in the young Muslim and blames him for the violence that has scarred his life. Sense prevails when the turbaned Sikh himself becomes a victim of racial violence and it's time for building bridges once again; time for hope and a little sugar to sweeten up the soured affairs.

Watch out for a touching performance by Anupam Kher, an actor who still carries the sparks of Saaransh within.

A re-make of Japanese cult filmmaker Takashi Miikes Chakushin Ari, this is unabashedly B-grade Hollywood. What was meant to keep you off cellphones, maybe forever, ends up as a thakela scary movie about a ghost who operates through today's most popular gizmo.

The victims receive a missed call that gives them a future recording of their death shrieks. Simply sounds scary, unlike the original which was a chilling story of a young girl who sees her friends dying nasty deaths after receiving terrifying sms-es on their cells. And the killer doesn't forget to leave a red candy in the dead person's mouth, a clue which leads to a forgotten story of child abuse and the consequent saga of revenge.

It's a brain-dead rendition which tells you to follow the title and leave the film as one missed call.
